DataElement.preferredName: Tumor Tissue Adequate Amount Obtained During Resection Descriptive Value
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Text term and number that represents the amount of tumor tissue obtained during surgery that met protocol defined thresholds.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Tumor Tissue Adequate Amount Obtained During Resection
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A tumor sample, or entire tumor that is removed for microscopic examination._Meeting a quantitative or qualitative measure necessary for a requirement; enough to meet the needs of a situation._How much there is of something that you can measure; the total amount or number._To come into possession of something._At some point in a given period of time._The act of cutting out; the surgical removal of part or all of a structure or organ.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A tissue sample, or entire tumor that is removed for microscopic examination.

Concepts.definition: Tissue sample that contains an abnormal cellular infiltrate forming a solid mass. The abnormal cellular component can be benign or malignant. Tumor samples are obtained for microscopic examination and/or molecular analysis.

Property.preferredDefinition: Meeting a quantitative or qualitative measure necessary for a requirement; enough to meet the needs of a situation.:How much there is of something that you can measure; the total amount or number.:To come into possession of something.:At some point in a given period of time.:The act of cutting out; the surgical removal of part or all of a structure or organ.

Concepts.definition: Meeting a quantitative or qualitative measure necessary for a requirement; enough to meet the needs of a situation.
How much there is of something that you can measure; the total amount or number.
To come into possession of something.
At some point in a given period of time.
The surgical removal of a lesion, often as part of a biopsy and with healthy margins.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: attributes of a patient's laboratory sample, including the source, condition, and fixative.

DataElementConcept.changeDescription:
Created for ABTC 1301 study in Rave per request by J.Zhao. mc 2/24/2014
Moved to ABTC Context mc 4/8/14

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A numerical quantity measured or assigned or computed.

PermissibleValues.value: Greater than or equal to 500 mg frozen tissue from contrast enhancing portion of tumor
PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Greater than or equal to 500 mg frozen tissue from contrast enhancing portion of tumor

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Greater than or equal to 500 mg frozen tissue from contrast enhancing portion of tumor
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A statement about the relative size or order of two objects specifying that either both objects are the same in quantity or measure or value or status or that the object of interest exceeds the other object in one of these ways.: A number with no fractional part, including the negative and positive numbers as well as zero.::500: A measure of weight.  A milligram is approximately 450,000 times smaller than a pound and 28,000 times smaller than an ounce.: A thin slice of tissue cut from a frozen specimen, often used for rapid microscopic diagnosis.: An enhancing lesion is a well-demarcated area of unequivocally increased signal intensity on T1-weighted spin-echo (SE) images compared with normal-appearing, surrounding tissue following intravenous injection of a gadolinium chelate.

Concepts.definition: A statement about the relative size or order of two objects specifying that either both objects are the same in quantity or measure or value or status or that the object of interest exceeds the other object in one of these ways.
A number with no fractional part, including the negative and positive numbers as well as zero.
A metric unit of mass equal to one thousandth of a gram or 1000 micrograms. One milligram equals approximately 0.015 432 grain or 35.274 x 10E-6 ounce.
A thin slice of tissue cut from a frozen specimen, often used for rapid microscopic diagnosis.

A well-defined area of unequivocally increased signal intensity on MRI or CT scan images compared with the normal-appearing surrounding tissues, following intravenous injection of gadolinium-based contrast material.
